instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SO: What is PP3V3_SO? PP3V3_SO is a typo of PP3V3_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
hi i have a 11" mac book air 
with green light orange light no power up
board looks very clean no previouse signs of work but it may have been cleaned.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  - 8.67v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>  - 0v

but no short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>

following <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> back i assume <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> creates this 

this has no 0v onvin on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>

power supply showes 0.03 amp at 18.5v

any help would be appreciated john

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
Post some voltages for <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>; pins 23, 13, 12, 22, 29, 21, 4.
Check for any pulse (at least) at pins 12, 21, 4; if no steady voltage detected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
voltages on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

23-  0V
13-  0V
12- 3.41V
22-  0V
29-  0.33V
21-  3.4V
4- 0V

No pulsing on 12,21,4

thank you again

john

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
bugger
i have now embarresed myself!!!
ppbus g3ht shorted the fuse had blown and i was testing the supply side so sorry
thanks again

john f

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
If you have no voltage on the VIN pin of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> check for a short on that pin. Also inspect closely that the trace isn't broken.

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present at 3.3 volts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
"ppbus g3ht shorted the fuse had blown"
Come back with comments when you get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
okay so i sorted out short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
 it was <CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR> shorted to earth 
this still will not post

voltages on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
23-    8.59v
13-    3.43v
12-    3.41v
22-    3.29v
29-    4.98v
21-     3.4v
4-         0v

no pulsing on
12
21
4
thank you john

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
You should get <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL> now; confirm that.
If yes, check <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
thats no to either of them
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
and 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SO</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
Resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL> coil?
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is enabled, change it if no short, or low value...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
hi so i have now got
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 

both of these are 3.21 but still the board will not turn on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message: to be fair i did not measure these correctlyin the first place

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.
If not, then post <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops at same time with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light orange light no power up
threads.message: hi so attached a small wire to <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR> to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and nothing on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  nothing on well 0.009v on <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and no volts on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> so no drop.
